title: Source Parsers - Directory Scrapers
description:
Build parsers to extract organization URLs from configured directories.

## Sources to Support

### 1. PublicSquare Marketplace
- URL: publicsquare.com/marketplace
- Structure: Category pages with business listings
- Extract: Business name, website, category
- Pagination: Load more / infinite scroll
- Rate limit: 10 req/min

### 2. Church Finder Directory
- URL: churchchurch.com or similar
- Structure: State > City > Church listings
- Extract: Church name, website, address, denomination
- Pagination: Standard page links
- Rate limit: 5 req/min

### 3. Christian Jobs Board
- URL: christianjobs.com or similar
- Structure: Job listings with employer info
- Extract: Employer name, website, industry
- Pagination: Standard
- Rate limit: 10 req/min

### 4. Kingdom Advisors Network
- URL: kingdomadvisors.com
- Structure: Member directory
- Extract: Advisor name, firm, website
- Monthly crawl only
- Rate limit: 5 req/min

## Implementation Approach
- Each source gets a parser function
- Parser returns array of {url, metadata}
- Metadata includes: name (if found), source, category
- URLs added to queue via bulkAddToQueue

## Technical
- Use fetch with proper headers
- Handle JS-rendered pages (may need Puppeteer for some)
- Respect robots.txt
- Store raw HTML for debugging

## Convex Functions
- `crawler.crawlSource` action - takes sourceId, runs parser
- `internal.crawler.parsePublicSquare`
- `internal.crawler.parseChurchFinder`
- etc.

title: Career Page Job Scraper
description:
Scrape actual job listings from organization career pages.

## Context
The crawler identifies organizations with career pages (has_careers_page=true). This feature extracts the actual job postings from those pages.

## Functionality
1. For orgs with has_careers_page=true, find their careers URL
2. Fetch and parse the careers page
3. Extract job listings: title, department, location, description, apply URL
4. Store jobs linked to the crawledOrganization
5. Mark jobs as "crawled" vs "posted" (by org directly)

## Career Page Patterns
- `/careers`, `/jobs`, `/careers/openings`
- Greenhouse, Lever, Workday, BambooHR embeds
- Custom career pages with job listings

## Job Schema Fields
- title, department, location (city/state/remote)
- employmentType (full-time, part-time, contract)
- salaryRange (if disclosed)
- description (truncated)
- applyUrl
- postedDate, expiresDate
- sourceType: "crawled" | "posted"
- crawledOrganizationId (link to org)

## Technical Approach
- After org classification, if has_careers_page, schedule job scrape
- Use common patterns to find job listings
- Store raw HTML for debugging
- Handle JS-rendered pages (Greenhouse, Lever APIs if possible)

## Edge Cases
- ATS systems with APIs (Greenhouse, Lever) - use API if available
- Paginated job listings
- Jobs with no posted date
- Duplicate detection (same job, new crawl)
close_reason: Job scraper implemented with career page detection, ATS pattern matching, AI extraction, and leadership markdown storage.

title: Track invitation relationships with directionality
description:
Track who invited whom to create an invitation tree/chain.

Rick
├── Sue (Rick's invite)
│   └── Bob (Sue's invite, Rick's downstream)
└── Jane (Rick's invite)

title: SMS authentication
description:
Add SMS/phone authentication using Brevo transactional SMS API.

## Requirements
- Users can sign up/login with phone number via SMS verification code
- Works alongside existing email and Google OAuth auth
- Invite code validation works with SMS auth

## Technical Details
- Provider: Brevo transactional SMS
- API Docs: https://developers.brevo.com/docs/transactional-sms-endpoints
- API Key: BREVO_SMS_API_KEY in .env.local (already configured)
- Convex Auth phone/SMS provider setup needed

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Users can enter phone number on signup
- [ ] SMS verification code sent via Brevo
- [ ] User enters code to verify
- [ ] Profile created after verification
- [ ] Works with invite flow
notes:
## SMS Auth UX Research (2026 Best Practices)

### Recommended Flow for Invite-Only Signup:
1. Validate invite code first
2. Show auth options: Phone | Email | Google (side-by-side)
3. Phone flow: Enter number → Receive 6-digit code → Verify → Onboarding

### Phone Input Best Practices:
- Use react-phone-number-input library (handles country codes, E.164 format)
- Auto-detect user's country
- Store in E.164 format (+12133734253)
- inputmode='numeric' and autocomplete='tel' attributes

### OTP Code UX:
- 6 digits (industry standard)
- 2-5 minute expiry
- Auto-advance between digit fields
- Support paste and SMS autofill (autocomplete='one-time-code')
- Auto-submit when complete
- Show countdown timer and resend option

### Security (Critical):
- Rate limit: 1 SMS per 30 sec, max 3 per 15 min per phone
- Max 3-5 code attempts before lockout
- Use crypto.randomInt() for code generation

### Brevo Integration:
- POST /transactionalSMS/sms endpoint
- Include sender name, recipient (E.164), content with code
- Handle delivery status callbacks

title: Design: Social connection metaphor (connect vs follow vs friend)
description:
Explore what social connection metaphor best fits Wonderwall's community of Christian creatives.

## Current State
- App has "Favorites" (one-way, bookmark-style)
- No mutual connection system yet
- Invite-only community with network stats

## Options to Consider

### 1. "Connect" (LinkedIn-style)
**Pros:**
- Implies mutual, bi-directional relationship
- Professional tone fits creative professionals
- Suggests collaboration potential
- More intimate than "follow"

**Cons:**
- Requires acceptance (adds friction)
- Can feel transactional/corporate
- Doesn't scale for creators with many admirers
- "Connection request pending" feels formal

### 2. "Follow" (Twitter/Instagram-style)
**Pros:**
- Familiar UX, low friction
- One-directional, no acceptance needed
- Scales well for popular creators
- Clear, understood paradigm

**Cons:**
- Impersonal, platform-y
- Implies hierarchy (follower vs followed)
- "Follower" has negative connotations for some Christians
- Doesn't encourage reciprocity

### 3. "Friend" (Facebook-style)
**Pros:**
- Warm, personal tone
- Fits community-focused values
- Implies mutual care

**Cons:**
- Requires acceptance (friction)
- "Unfriend" feels harsh
- Can feel dated/juvenile
- Awkward mixing personal + professional

### 4. Creative Alternatives

**"Crew" / "Add to Crew"**
- Fits production/creative industry language
- Implies collaboration, working together
- Could be asymmetric ("They're on my crew")

**"Circle" / "Inner Circle"**
- Community-oriented language
- Tiered possibilities (close circle vs wider)
- Google+ baggage though

**"Know" / "I know them"**
- Authentic real-world language
- "People you know" feels natural
- Awkward as action verb

**"Admire"**
- Positive, non-hierarchical
- Fits appreciating others' work
- One-way, like favorites

### 5. Keep Enhanced Favorites
- Don't add new system
- "Favorites" already works
- Add mutual indicator ("You're both favorites")
- Simplest approach

## Recommendation Considerations
- Community is invite-only, already somewhat intimate
- Christian values: mutual respect, not hierarchy
- Creative professionals: collaboration > fandom
- App name "Wonderwall" could inspire themed language

## Questions to Resolve
1. Do we need mutual connections, or is one-way sufficient?
2. Should connections unlock features (DMs, etc)?
3. How does this interact with existing Favorites?
4. What's the notification/acceptance UX?

title: Crawler Scheduler - Automated Runs
description:
Automate crawler runs based on source configuration.

## Scheduling Logic
Each source has:
- crawlFrequency: "daily", "weekly", "monthly", "manual"
- lastCrawledAt: timestamp
- isActive: boolean

Scheduler checks which sources are due and triggers crawls.

## Implementation Options

### Option A: Convex Crons (Recommended)
- Use Convex cron jobs feature
- Single cron runs every hour
- Checks which sources need crawling
- Queues URLs for due sources

### Option B: External Scheduler
- Cloudflare Worker with cron trigger
- Calls Convex HTTP endpoint
- More flexibility but external dependency

## Scheduler Logic
```
every hour:
  for each active source:
    if shouldCrawl(source):
      await crawlSource(source.id)
      updateLastCrawledAt(source.id)

shouldCrawl(source):
  if source.crawlFrequency === "manual": return false
  timeSinceLastCrawl = now - source.lastCrawledAt
  return timeSinceLastCrawl > frequencyToMs(source.crawlFrequency)
```

## Convex Functions
- `crons.ts` - define hourly cron
- `internal.crawler.checkScheduledCrawls` - main scheduler logic
- Update `crawlerSources` mutation to set lastCrawledAt

## Admin UI
- Show next scheduled crawl per source
- Override: "Skip next" or "Run now"
- Enable/disable scheduler globally

## FAQ Content to Include

### Invites
**Q: How do invites work?**
A: Each invite code can only be used once. When someone signs up using your invite code, it gets marked as "used" and cannot be reused.

**Q: How many invites can I create?**
A: You can create up to 3 invite codes at a time. Once an invite is used by someone, you can create a new one.

**Q: Can I see who used my invite?**
A: Currently, you can see if an invite has been used, but not who used it.

### Account
**Q: How do I reset my password?**
A: Password reset is not yet implemented. Contact support for help.

**Q: Can I change my email?**
A: Email changes are not currently supported.

### Profiles
**Q: How do I add a profile photo?**
A: Go to Settings and paste a URL to your profile image. We currently support URL-based images (e.g., from Gravatar, social media, or hosted services).

**Q: What are job functions?**
A: Job functions describe what you do creatively - Designer, Writer, Musician, etc. You can select multiple.

### Events
**Q: Who can create events?**
A: Any member can create events for the community.

**Q: What does "Approval required" mean?**
A: Event organizers can require approval before someone can attend. This helps manage capacity and ensure the right fit.

title: Queue Processor - Crawl Engine
description:
Build the core engine that processes the crawler queue.

## Functionality
1. Read pending URLs from crawlerQueue
2. Respect rate limits per source (requestsPerMinute from crawlerSources)
3. Call classifyUrl action for each URL
4. Update queue item status (completed/failed)
5. Handle retries with exponential backoff
6. Record crawler run stats

## Implementation Options

### Option A: Convex Scheduled Function
- Use ctx.scheduler to process queue items
- Self-rescheduling loop
- Pros: Simple, no external infra
- Cons: Limited concurrency, cold starts

### Option B: Convex Action with External Trigger
- HTTP endpoint that processes N items
- Called by external cron (Cloudflare Worker, Vercel Cron)
- Pros: More control, can run longer
- Cons: Need external scheduler

### Recommended: Option A for MVP
- Create `processQueue` internal action
- Processes 1-5 URLs per invocation
- Schedules itself for next batch after delay
- Respects source-specific rate limits

## Error Handling
- Max 3 retries per URL
- Exponential backoff: 1min, 5min, 30min
- After max retries, mark as failed with error message
- Alert (console log) on repeated failures

## Convex Functions Needed
- `internal.crawler.processNextBatch` - main processor
- `internal.crawler.scheduleNextRun` - self-scheduling
- `crawler.startQueueProcessor` - manual trigger from admin
- `crawler.stopQueueProcessor` - pause processing
- `crawler.getQueueStatus` - query for admin UI
close_reason: Queue processor complete with batch processing, retry logic, and admin UI. Upgraded to Llama 3.3 70B with json_schema structured output.
